numbered_ace_sentences: 1. In general, an applicant can have a parent.
2. The parent of an applicant can have an income percentile rank.
3. If the income percentile rank of the parent of an applicant is at least 90 then the applicant has a significantly greater chance to get accepted at an elite college.
4. If the income percentile rank of the parent of an applicant is at least 90 then the applicant can be up to 7 times more likely to get accepted at an elite college.
5. An applicant can be a legacy applicant.
6. An applicant can be a non-legacy applicant.
7. An applicant can be in an income bracket.
8. For every income bracket, a legacy applicant is more likely to get accepted than a non-legacy applicant.
9. Legacy boosts still exist.
10. I wonder why legacy boosts still exist.
11. Status can be favored over ability.
12. Income can be favored over ability.
13. I wonder why status is favored over ability.
14. I wonder why income is favored over ability.
15. Many people believe that college is synonymous with success.
16. Many people put a lot of time into meeting the criterion for attending elite schools.
17. Many people put a lot of effort into meeting the criterion for attending elite schools.
18. Some people are not considered because of their income.
19. Some people are not considered because of their status.
20. If people are not considered because of their income then wealth inequality becomes greater.
21. If people are not considered because of their status then wealth inequality becomes greater.
22. The headline is: The Legacy Continues, The Gap Widens.
